hints: The layers of gases surrounding Earth
Where all weather phenomena occur
Composed primarily of nitrogen and oxygen
An instrument used to measure air pressure
Falling readings often indicate a storm is coming
Can be either mercury or aneroid
An instrument used to measure wind speed
Often has three or four rotating cups
Essential for aviation and weather stations
A type of cloud that is puffy and cotton-like
Often described as 'fair weather' clouds
Can grow vertically into cumulonimbus clouds
The temperature at which air becomes saturated with moisture
At this point, condensation begins to form
A key indicator of humidity
The amount of water vapor in the air
Can be measured as absolute or relative
High levels make hot weather feel hotter
An instrument used to measure the amount of water vapor in the air
Used to determine the level of humidity
Can be found in weather stations
A line on a weather map
Connects points of equal atmospheric pressure
Closely spaced lines indicate strong winds
Water released from clouds as rain, snow, or hail
A crucial part of the water cycle
Measured with a rain gauge
A device orbiting Earth that provides weather data
Takes pictures of cloud formations and storms
Essential for global weather forecasting
An instrument used to measure temperature
Can use mercury, alcohol, or electronic sensors
A basic tool for all weather observations
A violently rotating column of air
Connects a storm cloud to the ground
Measured on the Fujita or Enhanced Fujita scale
The lowest layer of Earth's atmosphere
Where weather occurs and we live
Its temperature decreases with altitude
The boundary between two air masses of different densities
Can be warm, cold, stationary, or occluded
Often brings about changes in weather
A fast flowing, narrow air current
Found in the upper troposphere
Influences the movement of weather systems
A large scale air mass that rotates around a low pressure center
Can be a hurricane, typhoon, or tropical storm
Characterized by strong winds and heavy rainfall
A weather system with high atmospheric pressure
Air spirals outwards from the center
Associated with calm, clear weather
A cloud type that is flat and featureless
Often covers the entire sky like a blanket
Can produce light drizzle or mist
High-altitude, thin, wispy clouds
Made of ice crystals
Often indicates fair weather but can be a sign of a coming change
The transfer of heat by the movement of a fluid
Warm air rises and cool air sinks
A key process in storm development
A seasonal prevailing wind
Brings heavy rainfall during the summer months
Common in South Asia and Southeast Asia
A mature tropical cyclone
Occurs in the Northwest Pacific Ocean
The same phenomenon as a hurricane
A powerful tropical cyclone
Forms in the Atlantic or Northeast Pacific Oceans
Rated on the Saffir Simpson wind scale
An abnormal rise in sea level during a storm
Caused by strong winds pushing water ashore
The most dangerous part of a hurricane
A severe snowstorm with high winds
Reduced visibility due to blowing snow
Requires specific wind speed and duration criteria
A natural light display in the sky
Caused by solar wind particles entering the atmosphere
Also known as the Northern or Southern Lights
A bright spot of light in the sky
Appears on either side of the sun
Caused by light refracting through ice crystals
A multi-colored arc in the sky
Formed by light reflecting and refracting in water droplets
Appears opposite to the sun
A rotating column of air and spray over a body of water
Similar to a tornado but over water
Can lift small aquatic animals
Precipitation that evaporates before reaching the ground
Looks like a streak hanging from a cloud
Common in dry climates
The horizontal transfer of heat or a fluid
A key process for fog formation
Wind is a common example of this process
An instrument that measures altitude
Often a type of barometer that uses air pressure
Used by pilots and mountain climbers
The flat, top part of a cumulonimbus cloud
Forms when the cloud hits the top of the troposphere
Indicates a powerful thunderstorm
A temperature scale
Used in most parts of the world for weather reporting
Water freezes at zero degrees and boils at one hundred degrees
A temperature scale
Used primarily in the United States
Water freezes at 32 degrees and boils at 212 degrees
Pellets of ice that fall from thunderstorms
Formed by water droplets freezing in updrafts and downdrafts
Can cause significant damage
A large electrical discharge in the atmosphere
Can occur within a cloud, between clouds, or to the ground
Creates thunder
The daily disappearance of the sun below the horizon
Atmospheric scattering causes red and orange colors
The opposite of sunrise
The sound caused by lightning
The explosive heating of air creates a shockwave
Heard after the lightning flash is seen
An instrument that measures the amount of rainfall
Usually a cylinder with a funnel and a measuring scale
Can be manual or electronic
A type of radar used in meteorology
Measures precipitation and wind speed
Detects the movement of weather systems
A cold, dry wind
Flows down the Rhône River valley to the Mediterranean
Can affect agriculture and shipping

Reduces visibility
Forms when air cools and condenses
A type of air pollution
A mix of fog and smoke
Can cause respiratory problems

Found in polar regions

Keeps the planet warm enough to support life

Also known as a snow eater
Can cause rapid temperature increases
The process of a substance changing directly from solid to gas

The opposite of deposition
The process of a substance changing from liquid to gas
A key part of the water cycle
Driven by heat energy

Forms clouds, fog, and dew

Distinct from day-to-day weather

Often follows the opposite weather patterns of El Niño
The breakdown of rocks, soil, and minerals
Can be caused by wind, rain, and temperature changes
A fundamental geological process
A large, towering cloud
Often produces thunderstorms, hail, and tornadoes
Also known as a thunderhead
A low, lumpy layer of clouds
Often appears in rows or patches
Generally a sign of fair to poor weather
Mid-level clouds that are patchy and puffy
Often form in waves or bands
Can be a sign of a developing front
A high-level, thin, sheet-like cloud
Composed of ice crystals
Often creates a halo around the sun or moon
A low, dark, gray cloud
Produces continuous rain or snow
Lacks the anvil shape of a thunderstorm cloud
A thin layer of ice on a surface
Forms from deposition of water vapor on a cold surface
Requires temperatures below freezing
A cloud at ground level
Thinner than fog
Reduces visibility but less severely
A type of winter storm
Characterized by a significant amount of freezing rain
Can cause power outages and dangerous driving conditions
A prolonged period of excessively hot weather
Can be dangerous for human health
Often defined relative to a region's average climate
An atmospheric phenomenon
Caused by fine dry particles in the air
Reduces visibility and can make the sky appear milky
A strong, well-formed whirlwind
Forms on a clear day with little wind
Moves sand and dust upwards
A wind that blows from land to sea
Occurs at night
Caused by the land cooling faster than the sea
A wind that blows from sea to land
Occurs during the day
Caused by the land heating up faster than the sea
A line on a map
Connects points of equal precipitation
Used to show rainfall patterns
The reflectivity of a surface
A measure of how much solar radiation a surface reflects
Ice has a high value, while asphalt has a low one

Characterized by warmer-than-average sea surface temperatures
Can influence weather worldwide
